For measurable functions between a normed additive commutative group endowed with two measures, the integral of the function with respect to the sum of the measures equals the sum of the integrals with respect to each measure.

type:
‚àÄ {Œ± : Type u_1} {G : Type u_5} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup G] [inst_1 : NormedSpace ‚Ñù G] {m : MeasurableSpace Œ±}
  {Œº ŒΩ : MeasureTheory.Measure Œ±} {f : Œ± ‚Üí G},
  MeasureTheory.Integrable f Œº ‚Üí
    MeasureTheory.Integrable f ŒΩ ‚Üí ‚à´ (x : Œ±), f x ‚àÇ(Œº + ŒΩ) = ‚à´ (x : Œ±), f x ‚àÇŒº + ‚à´ (x : Œ±), f x ‚àÇŒΩ
name: MeasureTheory.integral_add_measure
docString: For measurable functions between a normed additive commutative group endowed with two measures, the integral of the function with respect to the sum of the measures equals the sum of the integrals with respect to each measure.

The theorem states that, for any types Œπ, E, F, given that E and F are both normed additive commutative groups and real vector spaces, and F is a complete space, along with a box 'I' of type 'BoxIntegral.Box Œπ' with Œπ being finite, integration parameters 'l', a function 'f' from Œπ ‚Üí ‚Ñù to E, and a volume 'vol' of type 'BoxIntegral.BoxAdditiveMap Œπ (E ‚ÜíL[‚Ñù] F) ‚ä§', a function is integrable with respect to these parameters and volume if and only if for all positive real numbers Œµ, there exists a function 'r' from non-negative real numbers (NNReal) to real numbers such that the function 'r' satisfies the R-condition for all 'c' in NNReal, and for any two non-negative real numbers 'c‚ÇÅ' and 'c‚ÇÇ' and any two tagged pre-partitions 'œÄ‚ÇÅ' and 'œÄ‚ÇÇ' of the box 'I', if both 'œÄ‚ÇÅ' and 'œÄ‚ÇÇ' are partitions of 'I' that satisfy the base set condition with respect to 'c‚ÇÅ', 'r c‚ÇÅ', 'c‚ÇÇ', and 'r c‚ÇÇ' respectively, then the distance between the integral sums of 'f' with respect to 'vol' over 'œÄ‚ÇÅ' and 'œÄ‚ÇÇ' is less than or equal to Œµ. In other words, the integral sums of the function form a Cauchy net, which is a generalization of the Cauchy sequence concept for sets with a more general structure than the real numbers.

type:
‚àÄ {Œπ : Type u} {E : Type v} {F : Type w} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup E] [inst_1 : NormedSpace ‚Ñù E]
  [inst_2 : NormedAddCommGroup F] [inst_3 : NormedSpace ‚Ñù F] {I : BoxIntegral.Box Œπ} [inst_4 : Fintype Œπ]
  {l : BoxIntegral.IntegrationParams} {f : (Œπ ‚Üí ‚Ñù) ‚Üí E} {vol : BoxIntegral.BoxAdditiveMap Œπ (E ‚ÜíL[‚Ñù] F) ‚ä§}
  [inst_5 : CompleteSpace F],
  BoxIntegral.Integrable I l f vol ‚Üî
    ‚àÄ Œµ > 0,
      ‚àÉ r,
        (‚àÄ (c : NNReal), l.RCond (r c)) ‚àß
          ‚àÄ (c‚ÇÅ c‚ÇÇ : NNReal) (œÄ‚ÇÅ œÄ‚ÇÇ : BoxIntegral.TaggedPrepartition I),
            l.MemBaseSet I c‚ÇÅ (r c‚ÇÅ) œÄ‚ÇÅ ‚Üí
              œÄ‚ÇÅ.IsPartition ‚Üí
                l.MemBaseSet I c‚ÇÇ (r c‚ÇÇ) œÄ‚ÇÇ ‚Üí
                  œÄ‚ÇÇ.IsPartition ‚Üí dist (BoxIntegral.integralSum f vol œÄ‚ÇÅ) (BoxIntegral.integralSum f vol œÄ‚ÇÇ) ‚â§ Œµ
name: BoxIntegral.integrable_iff_cauchy_basis
docString: The theorem states that, for any types Œπ, E, F, given that E and F are both normed additive commutative groups and real vector spaces, and F is a complete space, along with a box 'I' of type 'BoxIntegral.Box Œπ' with Œπ being finite, integration parameters 'l', a function 'f' from Œπ ‚Üí ‚Ñù to E, and a volume 'vol' of type 'BoxIntegral.BoxAdditiveMap Œπ (E ‚ÜíL[‚Ñù] F) ‚ä§', a function is integrable with respect to these parameters and volume if and only if for all positive real numbers Œµ, there exists a function 'r' from non-negative real numbers (NNReal) to real numbers such that the function 'r' satisfies the R-condition for all 'c' in NNReal, and for any two non-negative real numbers 'c‚ÇÅ' and 'c‚ÇÇ' and any two tagged pre-partitions 'œÄ‚ÇÅ' and 'œÄ‚ÇÇ' of the box 'I', if both 'œÄ‚ÇÅ' and 'œÄ‚ÇÇ' are partitions of 'I' that satisfy the base set condition with respect to 'c‚ÇÅ', 'r c‚ÇÅ', 'c‚ÇÇ', and 'r c‚ÇÇ' respectively, then the distance between the integral sums of 'f' with respect to 'vol' over 'œÄ‚ÇÅ' and 'œÄ‚ÇÇ' is less than or equal to Œµ. In other words, the integral sums of the function form a Cauchy net, which is a generalization of the Cauchy sequence concept for sets with a more general structure than the real numbers.

An integral domain is integrally closed if and only if it is equal to its integral closure in the field of fractions.

docString: An integral domain is integrally closed if and only if it is equal to its integral closure in the field of fractions.

This theorem states that for all real numbers 'a' and 'b' and for all functions 'f' and 'g' from the real numbers to a normed space 'E', if almost everywhere with respect to a given measure 'Œº', 'f' and 'g' are equal on the interval from 'a' to 'b', then the interval integrals of 'f' and 'g' over that interval with respect to 'Œº' are equal. This is a statement about the equality of integrals under the condition of almost everywhere equality of the functions being integrated.

name: intervalIntegral.integral_congr_ae
docString: This theorem states that for all real numbers 'a' and 'b' and for all functions 'f' and 'g' from the real numbers to a normed space 'E', if almost everywhere with respect to a given measure 'Œº', 'f' and 'g' are equal on the interval from 'a' to 'b', then the interval integrals of 'f' and 'g' over that interval with respect to 'Œº' are equal. This is a statement about the equality of integrals under the condition of almost everywhere equality of the functions being integrated.
